results.title: Reaching out: Ken Tyler - master printer
results.creator_credit: Avery, Tirce Productions, Lee Tirce and Sid Avery
results.brief_description: Highlights the relationship between the printer and artist by focusing on Ken Tyler who has worked with many significant artists including Roy Lichtenstein, David Hockney, and Robert Rauschenberg. He has influenced these artists in refining and enlarging upon the boundaries of the printmaking art. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Reaching out: a story about mainstreaming
results.creator_credit: Terry Dunn, Educational Media, Walt Disney Productions and John Cosgrove
results.brief_description: Looks at the difficulties and rewards of integrating the handicapped into regular classrooms. Shows Mary, a severely deaf child with limited speech capabilities and cerebral palsy, and how she copes with mainstreaming.

results.title: Reaching out
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Cynthia Connop and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ageing in the New Age”.
Looks at an experiment where the community is benefitting from utilising the previously wasted skill and wisdom of its old people. The results have two-way benefits: the older people feel happy to be contributing, and those helped are grateful for the assistance coming from the aged. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Reaching for the stars
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Australian news and Information Bureau, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Loch Townsend
results.brief_description: Shows Australian research in astronomy. Visits the observatory at Mount Stromolo, which houses big telescopes, cameras to map the skies, and the National Time Service. Goes on to show research on radio astronomy at the Radiophysics Laboratory (CSIRO), Sydney, and using Mills cross of stationary aerials and other devices. Pictures the windmill aerials at Dapto, used for tracking the sun

results.title: Reaching for the rainbow
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Sentinel”.
A twenty-man specialist Australian Army Engineers Unit is helping the Papua New Guinea Government with road-building and major works projects in the remote Southern Highlands Province of central Papua New Guinea. No other credits available.

results.title: Reach for the stars (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Teenagers’ guide to the galaxy”.
Part of a series developed for young people aged 9-16 which deals with issues of communication skills, interpersonal skills, life skills and problem solving. “Reach for the stars” is all about your potential, your future and what you will be doing for the rest of your life. It discusses how you can help achieve that path to success or make your dreams come true and includes hints and worldly advice from teenagers and adults about decision-making; career choices; motivation; setting goals; initiative; self belief and potential. Features Colette Mann as Fay.

results.title: Reach for the sky [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Daniel M. Angel, BFI and Lewis Gilbert
results.brief_description: This extract is from an early part of the biographical film on Douglas Bader. Bader’s crash (a result of showing off after being needled by civilians) resulted in the amputation of both his legs in December 1931. He has had a “peg leg” and crutches, but now he has met Thelma, who is working as a waitress and is determined to dance with her. The extract is concerned with the situations arising from Bader’s loss of legs and with his growing friendship with Thelma, who later becomes his wife. Cast includes Kenneth More, Muriel Pavlow, Sidney Tafler and Jack Walting.

results.title: Reach for the sky (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Daniel M. Angel, Rank Organisation Film Productions and Lewis Gilbert
results.brief_description: The acclaimed film biography of British World War II hero, Douglas Bader, who after losing both legs in an aeroplane crash, overcame insurmountable odds to become one of the most decorated and remarkable fighter aces in history. The film is based on the best-selling biography, “Douglas Bader”, written by Paul Brickhill. The film stars Kenneth More.
